text: @cricketcrocker Call me stupid, but I really don't understand how denying races is denying differences. I will concede, ppl are stupid and-
author: LinaLunaSparkle

text: @cricketcrocker That would be great! :) U can message me too, that way you won't have to work in this small space.
author: LinaLunaSparkle

text: @cricketcrocker - make such a clear statement, bc as a white European I of course do not have the same facts&view as a US POC.
author: LinaLunaSparkle

text: @cricketcrocker I don't see how denying human races denies a person's value. That said, I realize I am at the wrong side of the table to -
author: LinaLunaSparkle

text: @cricketcrocker I mean, it IS a taboo, but I can't say if it has basis in fact.
author: LinaLunaSparkle

text: @cricketcrocker My lenses are "non-biologist", "white" and "historically aware German". I don't know if the latter makes races a taboo here.
author: LinaLunaSparkle

text: @cricketcrocker I mean, can they be differences without being regarded as races?
author: LinaLunaSparkle

text: @cricketcrocker I'm not that good at biology: Do those differences mean that human races exist or are they just differences?
author: LinaLunaSparkle

text: @cricketcrocker I don't think I've ever denied differences. Is it that common with denying the human races concept?
author: LinaLunaSparkle

text: @cricketcrocker So, human races exist and it depends on how we approach the subject?
author: LinaLunaSparkle

text: @cricketcrocker But does genetic differences automatically mean that human races exist? I don't know if the idea is necessary to accept it.
author: LinaLunaSparkle

text: @cricketcrocker I just wonder, bc where I come from, the idea that human races exists is acknowledging a racial hierarchy.
author: LinaLunaSparkle

text: @cricketcrocker So, no escape then? If human races don't exist, it denies genetic differences and if they do, they still carry hierarchy?
author: LinaLunaSparkle

text: @cricketcrocker Ah, okay. I'm not sure I understand it entirely yet, but it makes more sense now.
author: LinaLunaSparkle

text: @cricketcrocker I'd like to think that accepting social race allows to focus on the social issues around it. Was that naive?
author: LinaLunaSparkle

text: @cricketcrocker How does it support value judgment? I really don't understand this, please explain if you don't mind.
author: LinaLunaSparkle

text: @cricketcrocker I kind of get it but I kind of don't. U say that bc u accept bio races or bc u think social race would've bad implications?
author: LinaLunaSparkle

text: @cricketcrocker I always like to remind ppl that while bio-race doesn't exist, social race does. I think that's a good compromise.
author: LinaLunaSparkle

text: @cricketcrocker thanks so much. Luckily I have a few hours of solid research activities planned to distract accordingly.

text: We understand #Natives in VA did this for selfpreservation. A reservation would be taken if they were too "negro". But it's no excuse now.
author: AzieDee

text: The Pamunkey (Pocahontas' people) were federally recognized this year. My family is still fighting for reinstatement. Racism goes beyond b&w
author: AzieDee

text: Around the #CivilWar, VA Indian tribes purged members with known black ancestry & made it against tribal law to marry black or "mullatos".
author: AzieDee

text: About a mile off the reservation. My cousins still live on Jesse's land. It's where we have our reunions. By the church & school he founded.
author: AzieDee

text: Jesse Dungey married MaryJane Custalow, daughter of the chief of the Mattaponi at the time. They lived on a farm by the #Pamunkey River.
author: AzieDee

text: @notvanishing yet, what's interesting is how fraudulent groups/pop up communities are now appropriating this language of kinship.

text: @notvanishing divorced from context, everyday, familial, and extended familial life. Given our immediacy, what does kinship look like?

text: @notvanishing yes. Like very literal. I'm not sure if you've experienced this, but the word 'kinship' is often employed poetically in ways
author: davidnbparent

text: @notvanishing totally. But, like what sort of kinships arrangements are being lived in the day to day?(Very interested in this w/ the urban)

text: @davidnbparent Ah, I see. You aren't the first person to ask me that (or other NDNs I know) and I guess it always kind of surprises me.
author: notvanishing

text: @justicedanielh These are the complexities erased by the nameless great-great-grandmothers, reducing our nations to cheekbones & princesses.
author: justicedanielh

text: @justicedanielh We won't always agree, but I'll listen, because they kept those fires. My family's struggles were connected, but different.
author: justicedanielh

text: @justicedanielh While I may be more inclusive in my definition of Cherokee identity than some whose families stayed, I won't condemn them.
author: justicedanielh

text: @justicedanielh That history matters. That context matters. Acknowledge it. Respect it. Honour it. And that's SO much more than blood.
author: justicedanielh

text: @justicedanielh I love & honour my family who made difficult choice to leave. But those who stayed kept the Nation alive for those who left.
author: justicedanielh

text: @justicedanielh More than one way to be Indigenous--always has been. But if we fetishize "blood" or DNA & erase the People, we've lost.

text: 13) And from where I sit, out, loud, and proud, nourished & nurtured by my family, friends, and community, that means we've already won.
author: justicedanielh

text: 12) But remember--you don't define us. We don't need you to hurt or feel shame. We don't need your approval. We don't need you, period.
author: justicedanielh

text: 11) No matter how hard you try, you won't win. And the harder you try, the more you *need* us to define yourself. So sad. And what a waste.
author: justicedanielh

text: 10) We don't need you. We don't need you to be miserable to be happy in our own lives, skins, and loves. We've earned those; we'll do fine.
author: justicedanielh

text: 9) We won't be miserable so that you won't feel regret. If our happiness indicts your ungrasped joys, that's on you. Deal with it.
author: justicedanielh

text: 8) You spend your whole life denying pleasure, desire, passion. And when we embrace those things, our happiness puts the lie to your claims.
author: justicedanielh

text: 7) But you need us. To feel shame, isolation, regret. Because as long as we don't, the emptiness of your self-righteousness is laid bare.
author: justicedanielh

text: 6) But you try to hurt us, shame us, degrade us--we'll fight. And we'll win, because we don't need you.
author: justicedanielh

text: 5) Our world is big enough for you to be you, too. We generally don't care what you do in your lives, your homes, your places of worship.
author: justicedanielh

text: 4) We've put up w/your sad, shaming, sanctimonious nonsense all our lives, and we still glitter and snap. You're WAY out of your league.
author: justicedanielh

text: @justicedanielh dude could flip a table like it was nobody's business
author: meakoopa

text: 3) Two things to keep in mind when you're up against out and proud folks: we've dealt with your bullshit all our lives. We *know* you.
author: justicedanielh

text: 2) Being dedicated to peace doesn't mean we don't fight back--we're just not defined by the need to hurt, diminish, marginalize others.
author: justicedanielh

text: Spec fic is about unlimited possibilities, so it's discouraging to see tired, hackneyed replication of oppressive stereotypes there too.
author: justicedanielh

text: This is why most Indigenous writers take these things so seriously--the settler-colonial "Indian" actively undermines Indigenous well-being.
author: justicedanielh

text: In the case of Indigenous peoples, stereotypes quite literally kill. They inform gov't policy, medical care, housing, family support, etc.
author: justicedanielh

text: @justicedanielh You're right. The better way for me to explain my confusion is... why do research on the physics of fiction & not culture?
author: somuchpanash

text: Serious writers will take the task seriously, with care, and with real thought about what goes into the world.
author: justicedanielh

text: None of this is to discourage--just a reminder that there's a huge, complex context we're dealing with, one with real material consequences.
author: justicedanielh

author: somuchpanash

text: We work for the space to imagine possibilities beyond the racism, colonialism, and bigotries we've inherited, & thus to make a better world.
author: justicedanielh

text: @justicedanielh whew all of this - thank you!
author: djolder

text: It's pretty sad when fantasy writers--who are supposed to be so creative--are unable to conjure up empathy for their Indigenous readers.
author: justicedanielh

text: But ultimately I think we have to support our own, b/c relying on others to create inclusive worlds will generally lead to disappointment.
author: justicedanielh

text: And I don't care if it seems trivial: I want awesome, *culturally grounded* Indigenous wizards in Rowling's world, b/c we belong there, too!
author: justicedanielh

text: The thing is, shouldn't only be POC & Indigenous folks doing this--writers with Ms. Rowling's resources & skill could share the labour too.
author: justicedanielh

text: In spite of all the backlash, the ugly trolling, & dismissive commentators, these folks are making space for us--& encouraging us to dream.
author: justicedanielh

text: Not to mention @Nnedi and @djolder, who took on the racist WFA shoggoths & helped shift conversation about race & racism in fantasy lit.
author: justicedanielh

text: In particular @NativeApprops and @debreese have faced HUGE backlash for their vital interventions, but that hasn't stopped their good work.
author: justicedanielh

text: It's why supporting our own writers matters so much--our peoples deserve imaginative worlds that don't simply reproduce oppression.
author: justicedanielh

text: Even then, Indigenous belonging *must* be about more than just descent; otherwise you become just another Washington Post polling troll.
author: justicedanielh

text: Responsibilities from tribal citizenship are largely about ensuring continuity of our collective nations, not just individual identities.
author: justicedanielh

text: It can't just be about laying claim to heritage, but accepting the responsibilities & obligations that come from those connections.
author: justicedanielh

text: Would I like to find that evidence? Sure--Chickasaws rock! But even if we did, it we'd have to learn our *responsibilities* as Chickasaws.
author: justicedanielh

text: As long as settler society sees Indig identity as consumable ethnic difference, our nations, lands, bodies, and identities are endangered.
author: justicedanielh

text: It's central to recent Lexi and Veronica adoption controversies, too. Not just theoretical: mainstream ignorance impacts real Indig lives.

text: @apihtawikosisan @ZoeSTodd @adamgaudry I want my babies to be proud to be Inuk and feel included. It would be heartbreaking otherwise.
author: tagaq

text: @tagaq @DocSteph yeah. I'm honestly sick of it. I write about it to purge it so I can move on. Want to do generative stuff.
author: apihtawikosisan

text: @tagaq @ZoeSTodd @adamgaudry ugh I hate those situations. It happens more than it should, hard to prove links. I know ppl who are FN
author: apihtawikosisan

text: @tagaq @ZoeSTodd @adamgaudry that's the thing...why fake it? I mean, there is PLENTY I don't know, I don't pretend I do. Lying is hard.
author: apihtawikosisan

text: @tagaq @DocSteph understandable. Not even a topic I ever wanted to get into until it started to trigger responsibilities.
author: apihtawikosisan

text: @tagaq @ZoeSTodd @adamgaudry so we had a situation where ppl said "I'm your sibling" and we found out it was true!
author: apihtawikosisan

text: @tagaq @ZoeSTodd @adamgaudry I mean, it's a process. Because it's not just an identity, they'd be related to someone too, right?
author: apihtawikosisan

text: @tagaq @ZoeSTodd @adamgaudry ahahahaahahahahaha....aya, we found out as adults, my grandpa had 2nd family down the road...omg.
author: apihtawikosisan

text: @tagaq @DocSteph oh it IS. Reconnecting is scary, and hard work. But rewarding, long term stuff.
author: apihtawikosisan

text: @tagaq Indigenous people have had to adapt. Extremely.
author: apihtawikosisan

text: @tagaq @ZoeSTodd @adamgaudry I could fill books with what I don't know, except they'd be empty. Don't ask me to name West Coast nations...
author: apihtawikosisan

author: apihtawikosisan

text: So a new ferry is well overdue.
author: Hayden_King

text: These are serious mobility issues and affect everyone, from kids going to school, people to work, just getting groceries is tough...
author: Hayden_King

text: One for the Island and one for the mainland. Most people don't have two cars so rely on taxis from Midland (30 mins away) to get around...
author: Hayden_King

text: Islanders use passenger ferry the "Indian Maiden", which itself is very old. But also requires people to have two cars...
author: Hayden_King

text: Spends every winter in drydock for weeks at a time and sometimes summer, too. Always requires repairs. When it's out of commission...
author: Hayden_King

text: The Sandy Graham ferry has been a workhorse for the Island for the past 20 years. But it's spent. The deck has collapsed multiple times...
author: Hayden_King

text:
Bottom line:

It isn't up to other People to tell you HOW to Feel.

No one should Minimise your Feelings or Reactions to Online Abuse.
author: DelSchilling

text:
Whatever you choose to do to feel safe, Do it.

We all Handle things in different ways & that is okay.

You deserve to Feel Safe.
author: DelSchilling

text:
Anyone that is facing Threats and Abuse Online, You are Not Alone.

I receive them.

The way you choose to handle them is Personal.  (Cont)
author: DelSchilling

text:
Abuse shouldn't be dismissed because it is happening in Online Spaces.

Abusers will use any tool to Abuse Others.  It shouldn't be ignored.
author: DelSchilling

text:
This is a New World we are Living in & "Online" Threats, have Real Life implications.
Online Spaces can and is often are weaponized.
author: DelSchilling

text:
Yes, There are trolls.

Yes, There are threats that won't be carried out, BUT that doesn't take away the way these threats affect you.
author: DelSchilling

text:
This is why threats on Social Media are NOT a Joke.

People that act like it doesn't matter, It really does.

A Threat Online IS Real Life.
author: DelSchilling

text:
This Situation is Horrific.

I think it's very important to address the fact that she was reportedly stalked Online.  (Cont.)

text: Even after the #IndianCitizenshipAct was passed, we were denied the right to vote in many states all the way up to 1957.

text: If you lived on the rez, you had to be granted a "pass" to leave.
author: mredshirtshaw

text: We were considered wards of the state until 1924 when ICA was passed and were denied various basic rights, including the right to travel.
author: mredshirtshaw

text: The guarantees of rights to African Americans contained in the 14th and Fifteenth Amendments did not extend to us.
author: mredshirtshaw

text: The Constitution of the United States had not recognized Natives as citizens.
author: mredshirtshaw

text: This land is my land. No colonial concept of patriotism can take away the blood memory that bleeds through me of this soil, hills, place.
author: mredshirtshaw

text: I am patriotic because my mother served in the Marines, because being Lakota is about honoring those we lost in our battles on this soil.
author: mredshirtshaw

text: I am patriotic because I love the land. But I can't honor a system with my ‚ù§Ô∏è that has tried to erase my culture. I want you to be better.
author: mredshirtshaw

text: In school, a Navajo friend and I would never put our hands over our ‚ù§Ô∏è for the Pledge/Anthem. Yes, you can quote me when I run for office.
author: mredshirtshaw

text: I don't even know what the correct answer to that question is but when it comes to bloodlines and the earth, me. All me. I "won."

text: We earn it. We deserve to claim Native if we honor our people.
author: mredshirtshaw

text: I carry blood memory/tradition/land connection/joy in my heart for my people - that has nothing to do with checking a box on an application.
author: mredshirtshaw

text: You're born with it. It's a commitment to a nation. It's an honor, a responsibility - to every youth, every elder who is connected to you.
author: mredshirtshaw

text: Here's the thing about being a real person, not a myth or a mascot or a golden ticket: it's not a sticker you wear when it's convenient.
author: mredshirtshaw

text: I am also a living real human being - with joy and sadness and devastation and bad days and good days and wrongdoings.
author: mredshirtshaw

text: I understand. I understand because I am Native American. And I would want to be Lakota even if I wasn't.
author: mredshirtshaw

text: I've never once looked back.
author: mredshirtshaw

text: When a girl I didn't stood up in my soc lecture & said she'd never seen a Native before, that this, would be, the every day, of my life.
author: mredshirtshaw

text: I would carry the responsibility of honoring my people no matter how heavy the weight, the responsibility, the honor, the courage had to be.
author: mredshirtshaw

text: As a student sitting in classrooms where I was the only Native, I realized I had a responsibility to my people that I would always carry.
author: mredshirtshaw

text: Those feelings of needing to honor my people, at 19, carried privilege & honor & anger. They carried joy & guilt. They CARRY responsibility.
author: mredshirtshaw

text:
What is the criteria for the top Google Image results we see? 
Can someone give me a breakdown of how these are chosen?
author: mredshirtshaw

text: When Google image searching "Asian American," at least one of the photographs has to do with stereotyping: http://t.co/c0y2ZJ6nWX

text: When Google image searching "African American," of the 20 top photographs, only 3 have women - and none are of women as features...why?

text: Looking deeply at when we Google Image search not only Native American, but African American, Asian American too... http://t.co/NCs54a8AQ5

text: Our ancestors paved the way for us & are a part of us. But by showing only them on Google image search, it erases our contemporary identity.

author: ErinIshimoticha

text: We have to talk to our Indigenous youth about feeling the responsibility of holding up hundreds of nations on their backs.
author: mredshirtshaw

text: I was the only Native student sitting in that lecture hall. I raised my hand, stood up, and said "Well...now you've seen one." Silence.
author: mredshirtshaw

text: Her response was "Well I've never met, much less SEEN a Native American, so I have no idea how they would feel about this issue."
author: mredshirtshaw

text: I remember sitting in a college lecture as a student and a non-Native student was responding to a question from the professor.
author: mredshirtshaw

text: When we as activists look back on our negative experiences, they have to be shared and learned from. We have to teach resolve.
author: mredshirtshaw

text: Becoming an activist is a responsibility that comes with highs and lows. There are people who will/won't believe in what you believe in.
author: mredshirtshaw

text: How, as activists out here who have been through these experiences, do we help young people navigate that responsibility?
author: mredshirtshaw

text: That's a ton of weight for a young person to be carrying - to be the only Native voice in a community: college, university, or a job.
author: mredshirtshaw

text: @mredshirtshaw Muslims in the west have this same issue. We're expected to represent a perceived monolith of 1 billion+ people.
author: hafiz_rashid

text: Sometimes, we meet someone who has never met a Native person so we as individuals are expected to hold up 567+ nations as one voice.

text: Too often do we talk about negativity w/ Natives - @NativeInAmerica seeks stories about light, hope and resiliency.  THAT'S YOUTH.
author: mredshirtshaw

text: The purpose of @NativeInAmerica is to show the world who Natives are as nation builders, leaders, hip hop artists, as contemporary citizens.
author: mredshirtshaw

text: If you haven't read the @NativeInAmerica stories, they are contemporary Native America. They are the future. They deserve recognition.
author: mredshirtshaw

text: Back in January, I reached out to a small group to start @NativeInAmerica & now we have 20 Native writers from all over the country/world.
author: mredshirtshaw

text: We can't be afraid of someone's celebrity status - if they are making you feel uncomfortable, they don't deserve a platform. Break it down.

text: @KimTallbear: "...of rapacious individualism, hierarchies of life, and ownership of land, bodies and desires‚Äù #c21landbody
author: AudraLMitchell

text: @KimTallBear 's concluding prayer: ‚ÄúMay your networks of love and relations be many, and not caged within settler-colonial norms... (1/2)
author: AudraLMitchell

text: @KimTallbear: Families not just personal choices: e.g. they affect whose children flourish and whose don't - human and nonhuman #c21landbody
author: AudraLMitchell

text: @KimTallbear: ‚ÄúFor us, materiality is part of beingness, not the other way around‚Äù #c21landbody
author: AudraLMitchell

text: @KimTallbear: in Dakota tradition, death of the body opens up another space of being, material and otherwise #c21landbody
author: AudraLMitchell

text: @KimTallbear: in Western materialist philosophy, death is feared because it marks the separation of spirit and matter #c21landbody
author: AudraLMitchell

text: @KimTallBear cites Kim Anderson's #Indigenous #feminism focused on care-taking of community and environment #c21landbody
author: AudraLMitchell

text: @KimTallBear : discourses of the  'sacred' forces one to accept the idea of the 'profane' - obscures complex relationality #c21landbody
author: AudraLMitchell

text: @KimTallBear :in Pipestone quarry, the stone is a relative #c21landbody
author: AudraLMitchell

text: @KimTallBear : the focus should not be on static '#indigenous #knowledge' but rather on the work being done by living #Indigenous thinkers
author: AudraLMitchell

text: @KimTallBear : there is exciting work to be done on these issues with #Indigenous communities from other parts of the world #c21landbody
author: AudraLMitchell

text: @KimTallBear : Western thinking has erected boundaries about what it is possible to know from empirical experience #c21landbody
author: AudraLMitchell

text: @KimTallBear :  finally some Western thinkers - new materialists - able to come to the conversation at the table of #Indigenous thinkers
author: AudraLMitchell

text: @KimTallBear : Sagan's account focuses on organismic life; Deloria's includes #nonhuman others not understood as 'living' #c21landbody
author: AudraLMitchell

text: @KimTallBear draws on resonances betw Vine Deloria Jr's American Indian Metaphysics and Dorion Sagan's interspecies communities #c21landbody
author: AudraLMitchell

text: @KimTallBear now discussing #indigenizing #interspecies thinking - including non-organisms such as stone and particular places #c21landbody
author: AudraLMitchell

text: @KimTallbear shares stories from her own ovate - strong kin relations in which women had strong authority - no single mothers  #c21landbody
author: AudraLMitchell

text: @KimTallBear the aspirational ideal of the normative middle-class nuclear family can be suffocating -  #c21landbody #gender #Indigeneity
author: AudraLMitchell

text: @KimTallBear : monogamous marriage co-produced with privatisation of land that targeted the power of #women in particular #c21landbody
author: AudraLMitchell

text: @KimTallbear : monogamous marriage at the root of sovereign nation-building designed to "save the man and kill the Indian" #C21landbody
author: AudraLMitchell

text: @KimTallBear 's new work critiques #settler #sexualities & #natures focused on future-hoarding of love and the bodies of others #c21landbody
author: AudraLMitchell

text: @KimTallBear new work: #Indigenous #relationality critiquing hetero- & homo-normative coupleism, life/not life, hierarchy #c21landbody
author: AudraLMitchell

author: jfkeeler

text: @PostPolls You have to state clearly how & why they should be singled out and featured to give their opinions any added weight over the rest
author: jfkeeler

text: @PostPolls Also, Prof. Fenelon took issue w/WaPo using random quantitative data qualitatively (12 featured) w/out methodology of how chosen.
author: jfkeeler

text: @PostPolls I think you'd need a much larger respondent group to smooth over for these inconsistencies.
author: jfkeeler

text: @PostPolls Also respondents demographically don't track with Native pop. Mostly male, over 50 years of age and from the South.
author: jfkeeler

text: @PostPolls It it also true that this poll was done as part of an omnibus of changing questions?
author: jfkeeler

text: @PostPolls I think weighting self-reported NA identity is important because there is a real tendency to misreport. 29% is reasonable.
author: jfkeeler

text: @EduardoAsus24 You have to ask all respondents the exact same questions. Pollsters had different questions each week. It's not comparable.
author: jfkeeler

text: @EduardoAsus24 So, they would have to get 1950 self-identified NA responses. It took 28,000 calls to get the 504. So need to call 108,333.
author: jfkeeler

text: @EduardoAsus24 This (353) is not a large enough sample. They would need 1500 to smooth out all the inconsistencies.

text: Nothing is more healing than coming home üíú
author: FrankWaln

text: Thank you to everyone who made it possible. Thank you to Kodi and @RollieRaps. Thank you to everyone who helped me make my dream a reality
author: FrankWaln

text: I'm exhausted but I'm happy and grateful. Getting this type of reception and love from home today changed my life forever
author: FrankWaln

text: I was so moved. I was reminded that I was born to do this. All the sacrifice and setbacks I faced were not in vain
author: FrankWaln

text: @FrankWaln STATEMENT
author: OnePageWriter

text: A young lady asked me to sign her arm. Her wrist was covered in scars from cutting. I signed over the scars & she hugged me
author: FrankWaln

text: I saw my kindergarten teacher for the first time in a long time. She said she's proud of me and said "good thing I taught you to read" lmao
author: FrankWaln

text: They made me so many thank you cards https://t.co/TsFsi6t5Wp
author: FrankWaln

text: I told them that I'm so proud of being Lakota & I'm so proud of where I'm from. I told them they inspire me & give me hope when I struggle
author: FrankWaln

text: We got thru today on our Rez. I didn't learn these things until I was in my 20's. I told them we descended from greatness. We are Lakota
author: FrankWaln

text: When I was onstage and in class, I told them about the history of colonization & genocide our ancestors faced and how that relates to what
author: FrankWaln

text: I told them how I wish I could be home to learn our language but I'm on the road, to cherish that and to learn as much as they can
author: FrankWaln

text: I told them what a privilege it is to have a Lakota language class at a young age. I didn't get that when I was their age
author: FrankWaln

text: Todd County Middle School Lakota language class. I told them how beautiful & important our culture & language are https://t.co/RK66nsV8Z6
author: FrankWaln

text: After the performance, I visited their Lakota language class. They showed me what they're learning https://t.co/4qqL4MdWkL
author: FrankWaln

text: I gave them everything I had onstage. I bawled my eyes out performing to my mom. I don't get to see her often and miss her everyday
author: FrankWaln

text: Kodi DeNoyer performed with me again.I brought my mom onstage & performed My Stone to her in front of all those kids https://t.co/NH0hZwzYeL
author: FrankWaln

text: @FrankWaln The impact you have on the youth is astoundingly beautiful üò≠üò≠üò≠
author: AALEYEH

text: This was the first time I realized that I was poor, that white privilege is real and that higher education isn't built for ppl like me
author: FrankWaln

text: I told the students on the service trip that I attended the same school they did. They didn't believe me. I had to show them my student ID
author: FrankWaln

text: I'll never forget when I went home for fall break freshmen yr. The university I attended was doing a damn service trip in my home community
author: FrankWaln

text: I graduated 1st in my class in high school. Got the Gates Millennium scholarship and left the Rez to attend a private school to study premed
author: FrankWaln

text: And #WeAreStillHere! I never feel ashamed, I feel blessed to be Yakama. @FrankWaln

text: @DeLesslin We are starting to repeat our main points,& twitter is not conducive to anythig more in depth. Feel free to have the "last word."
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin Ethic/tribal identities were.  Europeans were just a new market for already huge slave markets.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin But the people who embody that civic heritage can and are.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin That was the fault of disease.  Pandemics happen - hardly a plot by the so-called "Kyriarchy"
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin Germany and Japan, OTOH, might agree with me.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin Other Blacks in Africa, also, the Arabs.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin America isn't a tool, period.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin The Algonquians might disagree with you.  FIghting, conquest, and oppression were well known in Americas before Columbus.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin which is why absolute equality is impossible, biologically speaking.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin The many abolitionist societies proves you wrong.  Whites didn't invent Black slavery, they ended it.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin America cares.  Anglo-sphere countries and some others in Western Civilization cares.  No one else would give a damn.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin The differences are not manichean.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin Yes. Displacement/replacement of peoples has been historical norm for societies. That America feels guilt is proof of that.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin But it is indicative of what I've seen.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin Physical body build, brain wiring, hormones & other biochemical aspects, &c.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin No, they argue about abolishing Whiteness and how "smartness" oppresses similarly.  The full paper states that explicitly.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin Same thing.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin False.  It's root has been civic in nature.  Racial/ethnic tribalism has been default norm in history, America transcended it.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin "Social Justice" is about fighting the "kyriarchy" & such -  Discriminating against, men, Whites, &c. to overthrow "kyriarchy"
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin As far as equal application of the law, than in general yes. But not ignoring obvious differences between the sexes.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin And furries feel they are a different species rather than just a different sex.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin The ones in the paper.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin America is based on a civic heritage.  Don't destroy that and replace it with one that defines its ideology on race.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin America also shows historically to be capable of great inclusiveness.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin Affirmative Action is inequality before the law.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin % of bachlors going to men is <50%, and still falling.  That's ain't "equitable"
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin Mostly been that way for a century, save for right after WWII due to G.I. Bill of Rights
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin Majority of bachelors has long been earned by women, more so with many female dominated majors.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin Aside from some rare medical anomalies, the distinction between man and woman is pretty obvious.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin Because "1 + 1 = 2" is a social construct?  The article goes on a rant about the need to destroy "whiteness"
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin  Plenty in the references.  As for others, I don't keep a full list on hand.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin Correlation != Causation
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin When that "equal opportunity" is nothing more than discrimination, e.g. Affirmative Action.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin Mentioned in here: http://t.co/1d2lMS5q4T
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin Wrong, it designate one group, who dominate through "interlocking hierarchies."
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin You can't be against inequality when you are fightin for and with it.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin A system that *demands* inequality is an unjust and unequal one.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin That "rebalancing" is itself discriminatory and unequal!
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin You assume that there is a proactive mechanism that is specifically racial, sex-based, &c. that exists.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin And what do you mean by "equitable"
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin You cannot create a more just society by fighting for one that is unjust.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin "Justice" is usually defined by the Leftist academics to mean an equality of outcome.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin Spiffy, then you accept that outcomes might not be statistically equal or equivalent?
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin What you are advocating is not just.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin The "Ciritical Studies" schmucks explicitly define "Whiteness" as "false and oppressive" & that it must all go.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin The tenant "fights" "kyriarchy" by treating people unequally.  E.g. Affirmative Action
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin Again, it depends on what you mean by "equality"
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin Plenty of social factors aside from racist plots of oppression.  Illegitimacy is one such example.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin That does not equate to structural racism.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin You can not "fight for equitable and just system" by opposing a mostly good one and fighting for one that is not.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin American society is at its core just, and equitable when it comes to the law.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin Equal application of the law and having everyone subject tot hat same law is good.  Forced equality of outcome is false.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin The rule of law that we are all subjected to is our societies core value.  The rabid Left rejects this.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin That by targeting and eliminating "Whiteness" can all races be "equal"?
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin "worth" is far to subjective to use in an argument.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin The problem is that those who wish to overthrow this "kyriarchy" can only think in terms of treating people unequally.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin Which particular gap?
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin You assume that any inequality is due to the structural and intentional "privilege" of the designated boogie-man group.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin What do you mean by "equal"?
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin I reject such limited viewpoints.  It is a sad, sad worldview.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin The problem it that that Leftist ideology can only think in those terms.  "Privilege" is not the root of American society.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin This is why we can be guilted by accusations that are demonstratively false.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin It ignores that American society is far more tolerant and inclusive than most others throughout history.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin Much of the "privilege" talk is nonsense.  It blames the status quo as the root of this evil, and goodness the absence thereof
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin @drtantatinycat LOL, at least I've retained enough logic to see "Kyriarchy" for what it is.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin All it does is try to justify blaming everything on straights, Whites, &c.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin I have questioned the "assumption" of Kyriarchy and found it to be hate filled and bigoted.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin It is not an open inquiry, but an excuse to criticize and bring down others.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin The problem is that what the frothing Left (who rant about "Kyriarchy") is far, far worse.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin Society evolves and changes on its own.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin You confuse idiocy like "Kyriarchy" with reality.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin "Kyriarchy" is just justification for assigning and blaming a boogie-man.  It is false and oppressive‚Ä¶ and hypocritical.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin Perhaps you should interrogate your own assumptions.  Question "Kyriarchy" and the entire narrative.
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin Yet it always tends to start with a presumption which is then validated?
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin Or Western Civilization in general. The common thread of the rabid Left: Tear down society and replace it with their own utopia
author: ThePoliticalHat

text: .@DeLesslin There is little more hierarchical than a false imposed "non-hierarchical equality."  And yes, it is the schtick of the Left
author: ThePoliticalHat
